newsitem.title: UK: London precious metals tick higher, mood sweetens.
newsitem.headline: London precious metals tick higher, mood sweetens.

text.p: Precious metals prices climbed higher in a bullish mood in early trading on Tuesday, extending gains posted the previous day, dealers said.
"Gold broke out of its $378-$382 range and the market is very bullish," a dealer said. "It was holding at $380 for so long the market was frustrated and decided to try the upside."
Bullion fixed at $382.40 an ounce, compared to $381.00 on Monday afternoon and a London closing of $381.50/$382.00.
Further tests of upside resistance were likely, dealers and analysts said, although some added that gains were probably limited and possibly shortlived.
Gold drifted to 18-month lows earlier this month, undermined by indifference from investors and speculators and weaker than expected demand from the jewellery industry.

"I'm not convinced. I think we're just in a new $381-$383 range. The producer selling that was around last week to depress prices is still around," the dealer said. Strong resistance was expected at around $384 an ounce.
Still, a series of uptrending technical indicators on historical price charts suggested a forthcoming upswing, some technical analysts said.
"The sudden bursts of strength enjoyed by gold, platinum and silver yesterday much reduces downside risk," analyst Elli Gifford of Investment Research of Cambridge said in a report.
"Indeed there is a possibility the lows have been seen and a bout of worthwhile corrective strength could soon come through."

Gold prices have broken above a medium-term downtrend line which joins the peak of the February 1996 rally with highs in late August. A close above the trendline, currently at $381.60 an ounce, would confirm that breach, analysts said.

Also contributing to a more positive technical picture, the 10-day moving average was on the verge of crossing the 30-day moving average on the upside, while the 14-day RSI was trending up from oversold positions earlier this month.
Silver followed gold higher and was trading at $4.95/$4.97 an ounce, up two cents from Monday's London close.
"It ended at the top end of its $4.87-$4.93 range on Monday. It seemed to have tagged along for the ride," a dealer said. The psychological $5.00 was silver's key hurdle.
Platinum was trading $1.00 stronger compared to Monday's finish at $384.50/$385.50 an ounce. Palladium was $0.50 firmer at $117.00/$118.00. --Lida Poletz, London newsroom +44 171 542 2936
